title: Balancing Pitta
author: Sign In
description: If pitta dosha is out of balance, you might feel overly critical, irritated, and overheated. Learn more about Ayurvedic strategies to soothe excess pitta.
cleaned_text: Balancing Pitta Pitta is the energy of fire and water, digestion, and transformation. When in healthy balance, this dosha brings intelligence, charisma, courage, clarity, and the light of understanding. In excess, it can cause imbalances related to excess heat, such as anger, jealousy, irritated skin, sharp hunger, and difficulty sleeping. Signs and Symptoms of Pitta Imbalance [Is your pitta out of balance?](https://www.banyanbotanicals.com/info/dosha-quiz/) If so, you may be experiencing some of the following signs or symptoms: - Red or irritated skin - Burning digestion and an overactive metabolism - Nausea or discomfort upon missing meals - Loose stools - An uncomfortable feeling of heat in the body - Feelings of frustration, anger, and irritability - Judgment, impatience, criticism, and intolerance - Red, dry, or light-sensitive eyes - Excessive perfectionist tendencies To decrease pitta, [Ayurveda](https://www.banyanbotanicals.com/info/ayurvedic-living/learning-ayurveda/intro-to-ayurveda/) has given us dietary, lifestyle, and herbal treatment strategies. Here are a few underlying concepts that these strategies are based on, designed to bring balance to the heat and intensity of pitta: - Cooling - Surrendering - Moderation General Guidelines for a Pitta-Balancing Diet The following dietary recommendations are general guidelines for balancing pitta, but Ayurveda encourages listening to your own body and making food choices that are right for you. Some pitta-types have a particularly strong digestive fire and find that they can tolerate more varieties of food than others. Enjoy: - Foods that are naturally [sweet](https://www.banyanbotanicals.com/info/ayurvedic-living/living-ayurveda/diet/six-tastes/sweet-taste/), [bitter](https://www.banyanbotanicals.com/info/ayurvedic-living/living-ayurveda/diet/six-tastes/bitter-taste/), and [astringent](https://www.banyanbotanicals.com/info/ayurvedic-living/living-ayurveda/diet/six-tastes/astringent-taste/). - Cooling foods, both energetically and in temperature. - A balance of whole, freshly cooked foods and fresh, raw foods. - Most beans. - Cooling herbs and spices like [coriander](https://www.banyanbotanicals.com/coriander-powder/), cilantro, [fennel](https://www.banyanbotanicals.com/fennel-powder/), and [cardamom](https://www.banyanbotanicals.com/cardamom-powder/). - Dairy, if you digest it well, but avoid drinking milk with your meals. It is best to have it at least an hour before or after other food. - Condiments that are cooling and sweet in nature, such as cucumber raita, cilantro chutney, or a creamy avocado salad dressing. - A moderate amount of high-quality olive, sunflower, and coconut oils or [ghee](https://www.banyanbotanicals.com/organic-ghee/)in your daily diet. - Soothing herbal teas, such as lemongrass, rose, licorice, mint, or [Mellow Mind](https://www.banyanbotanicals.com/mellow-mind/?product_sizes=292). - Routine times for your meals. - Taking a deep breath after swallowing your last bite and heading off for your next activity. - Eating your meal in a peaceful environment. Avoid: - Foods that are [pungent](https://www.banyanbotanicals.com/info/ayurvedic-living/living-ayurveda/diet/six-tastes/pungent-taste/), [sour](https://www.banyanbotanicals.com/info/ayurvedic-living/living-ayurveda/diet/six-tastes/sour-taste/), and [salty](https://www.banyanbotanicals.com/info/ayurvedic-living/living-ayurveda/diet/six-tastes/salty-taste/). - Warming foods, both energetically and in temperature. - Spicy foods like chili and cayenne peppers. - Highly processed foods (like canned or frozen foods, TV dinners, or pastries). - Eating fresh fruit or drinking fruit juice in combination with other foods. - Caffeine, nicotine, and other stimulants. If you are a coffee lover, add milk or almond milk to balance its effects. - Red meat. - Deep fried foods. - Alcohol, except for an occasional beer or white wine. Pitta-Balancing Herbs [Ayurvedic herbs](https://www.banyanbotanicals.com/info/plants/ayurvedic-herbs/) are useful allies when it comes to balancing the doshas. Ayurveda has a long history detailing the use of herbs and herbal combinations to cool the heat of pitta and support balance in the body and mind. Below are some herbs and formulations that are especially useful for balancing pitta. [Amalaki](https://www.banyanbotanicals.com/amalaki-powder/)is one of the quintessential Ayurvedic herbs for supporting healthy pitta. [Healthy Pitta](https://www.banyanbotanicals.com/healthy-pitta-tablets-10/)combines excess pitta in the joints. and a [Mental Clarity](https://www.banyanbotanicals.com/mental-clarity-tablets-10/)can help ease imbalanced pitta anger, judgment, impatience, and criticism. [Triphala powder](https://www.banyanbotanicals.com/triphala-powder/)or [tablets](https://www.banyanbotanicals.com/triphala-tablets-11/)can not only soothe the eyes and support their proper function, but also support healthy digestion and elimination. General Guidelines for a Pitta-Pacifying Lifestyle Enjoy: - Surrendering rather than controlling. - A supportive [daily routine](https://www.banyanbotanicals.com/info/ayurvedic-living/living-ayurveda/lifestyle/introduction-to-daily-routine/)with regular times for eating, sleeping, working, and so on. Make sure you make time to play and to relax as well as to work. - A [daily self-massage](/info/ayurvedic-living/living-ayurveda/lifestyle/self-oil-massage/)with warm [coconut oil](https://www.banyanbotanicals.com/coconut-oil/), A moderate [exercise routine](https://www.banyanbotanicals.com/info/ayurvedic-living/living-ayurveda/health-guides/the-ayurvedic-approach-to-fitness/a-pitta-pacifying-approach-to-fitness/)that includes a challenging form of yoga, swimming, or biking, about five times per week. Avoid exercising during the hot part of the day. - Keeping your mind and body cool. - Sweet and soothing music, smells, scenes, and company. - Giving yourself ample time to wind down in the evenings without screens or to-do lists. - Going to bed by 10 p.m. to support sound, restful sleep. Our lives, environments, and health change regularly. We recommend that you take our [dosha quiz](https://www.banyanbotanicals.com/info/dosha-quiz/) periodically to see what has changed, keeping in mind that it's possible to have more than one dosha out of balance at once. Check out our guides to [managing your constitution](https://www.banyanbotanicals.com/info/ayurvedic-living/learning-ayurveda/managing-your-constitution/) to decide which remedies are most beneficial to you.
